description: A classic, hearty one-pot dish where unripe green bananas (matoke) are steamed and cooked together with a flavorful beef stew. The matoke absorbs the rich, spiced broth from the meat, resulting in a tender, savory, and comforting meal.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: Katogo is the ultimate Ugandan comfort food, famously eaten as a substantial breakfast that provides energy for the whole day. It is a symbol of home-cooked simplicity and is often prepared for large families. The term 'Katogo' broadly refers to any one-pot meal mixing a carbohydrate with a sauce, but the matoke and beef version is a quintessential favorite.

ingredients.name: Unripe Green Bananas
ingredients.notes: Peeled and kept in salted water to prevent browning

steps.instruction: Heat the cooking oil in a heavy-bottomed pot over medium heat. Add the chopped onions and saut√© until soft and translucent.
Add the cubed beef and brown on all sides for about 5-7 minutes.
Stir in the chopped tomatoes, tomato paste, and salt. Cook until the tomatoes break down and form a thick sauce, about 10 minutes.
Add 1 cup of water, cover the pot, and let the beef simmer on low heat for about 45 minutes, or until the beef is tender.
Drain the peeled matoke and add them to the pot, nestling them into the beef stew.
Cover the pot tightly and let everything steam together on low heat for another 25-35 minutes, or until the matoke is very tender. Do not stir vigorously; gently shake the pot occasionally.
Once the matoke is soft and has absorbed the stew flavors, gently mash them slightly with the back of the spoon into the sauce.
Serve hot in a bowl, ensuring each portion has both matoke and beef stew.

serving_suggestions: Traditionally served on its own as a complete meal for breakfast or lunch. It can be accompanied by a slice of avocado or a side of leafy greens.
